thread.title: Parties to vote on working toward lease of potential St. Paul soccer stadium site
thread.title_full: Parties to vote on working toward lease of potential St. Paul soccer stadium site - StarTribune.com

author: Kevin Duchschere
title: Parties to vote on working toward lease of potential St. Paul soccer stadium site
text:
The St. Paul City Council, the city’s Port Authority and the Metropolitan Council will vote next week on an agreement to work toward leasing a vacant Met Council site in the Midway district for a professional soccer stadium.
The agreement paves the way for formal negotiations among the parties to put together a long-term lease by the city of St. Paul for the 10-acre site, which would continue to be owned by the Met Council.
The Port Authority, serving as the city’s agent, already has been in talks with Met Council officials for several weeks on a possible deal.
The agreement signals continuing interest and momentum for St. Paul’s bid for the project, which began in earnest last summer after Minneapolis officials failed to put forth a stadium proposal for the North Loop.
But the deal is still far from done. Minnesota United FC owner Bill McGuire and his investors are seeking tax breaks for the stadium site, which would require legislative action next year.
And even if a lease agreement is reached, the final decision on a stadium location for the Minnesota United FC team would still have to be made by Major League Soccer.
McGuire and the investment group have said they would foot the costs of building the 18,500-seat stadium, estimated to be about $120 million. That is the condition under which the St. Paul City Council has said it would favor exempting the site from property taxes.
The city would own the soccer stadium once it’s built, under the terms of the joint powers agreement to be considered next week. And the Met Council would continue to own the property, which would be developed with facilities such as kiosks, plazas, walkways and other transit-friendly amenities.
